Making Process:
Peel and chop 1 kg of potatoes into medium-sized cubes and keep them in water to prevent browning.
Finely chop 1 kg of onions and 1 kg of tomatoes, or blend the tomatoes into a puree for a smoother consistency.
Heat 200 ml of oil in a large pan on medium heat.
Add the chopped onions to the hot oil and Saute until they turn golden brown.
Once the onions are well cooked, add 2 tablespoons of chili powder and mix well, allowing the spices to blend.
Add the chopped or pureed tomatoes and stir well to combine with the onions.
Cook the mixture for a few minutes until the tomatoes turn soft and the oil starts separating from the masala.
Add the cubed potatoes to the pan and mix thoroughly, ensuring they are well coated with the onion-tomato mixture.
Sprinkle 2 tablespoons of salt over the potatoes and stir everything together.
Cover the pan with a lid and cook the potatoes on low heat for about 5 minutes.
After 5 minutes, add 500 ml of water and mix well to create a curry consistency.
Increase the flame to medium-high and bring the curry to a boil.
Once it starts boiling, reduce the heat to medium and let the curry simmer.
Stir occasionally to prevent sticking and to ensure even cooking.
Allow the potatoes to absorb the flavors and cook until they turn soft.
If the curry appears too thick, add a little more water to adjust the consistency.
Taste and adjust the salt or chili powder as per your preference.
Simmer for another 2-3 minutes, allowing all the flavors to blend well.
Once the potatoes are fully cooked and the curry reaches the desired consistency, turn off the heat.
Let the curry rest for a couple of minutes before serving.
Serve hot with steamed rice, roti, or chapati for a delicious meal.

Peel and chop 1 kg of potatoes into thin slices or small cubes and keep them in water to avoid discoloration.
Finely chop 1 kg of onions and 1 kg of tomatoes, keeping them ready for cooking.
Heat 200 ml of oil in a large pan or wok over medium heat.
Add the chopped onions to the hot oil and Saute until they turn soft and slightly golden brown.
Once the onions are well-cooked, add 2 tablespoons of chili powder and mix thoroughly.
Add the chopped potatoes and stir well, ensuring they are evenly coated with the onions and spices.
Cover the pan with a lid and cook on low heat for about 5 minutes, allowing the potatoes to soften.
Stir occasionally to prevent sticking and ensure even cooking.
Once the potatoes are partially cooked, add the chopped tomatoes and mix well.
Sprinkle 2 tablespoons of salt over the mixture and stir to combine all the ingredients.
Increase the heat to medium and continue cooking without a lid, allowing excess moisture to evaporate.
Stir occasionally to prevent burning and ensure uniform frying of the potatoes and tomatoes.
Let the mixture cook for another 10-15 minutes, stirring every few minutes.
As the tomatoes break down, they will form a slightly thick coating around the potatoes and onions.
Check if the potatoes are fully cooked by piercing them with a fork. If they are soft, proceed to the next step.
Continue frying for a few more minutes until the mixture turns slightly crispy and golden brown.
Adjust the salt or chili powder if needed, based on taste preference.
Stir well to ensure all the spices and flavors are evenly distributed.
Turn off the heat once the potatoes are fully cooked and have a slightly crisp texture.
Let the stir-fry rest for a minute before serving.
Serve hot as a side dish with chapati, roti, or steamed rice for a flavorful meal.

Peel and chop 1 kg of potatoes into medium-sized cubes and keep them in water to prevent browning.
Finely chop 1 kg of onions and 1 kg of tomatoes, or blend the tomatoes into a smooth puree for a richer gravy.
Heat 200 ml of oil in a large pan or kadhai over medium heat.
Add the chopped onions to the hot oil and Saute until they turn golden brown.
Once the onions are well-cooked, add 2 tablespoons of chili powder and mix well.
Add the chopped or pureed tomatoes and stir to combine with the onions.
Cook the mixture for a few minutes until the tomatoes soften and the oil starts separating from the masala.
Add the cubed potatoes to the pan and mix thoroughly, ensuring they are well coated with the onion-tomato mixture.
Sprinkle 2 tablespoons of salt over the potatoes and stir well.
Cover the pan with a lid and cook on low heat for about 5 minutes.
After 5 minutes, add 750 ml of water and mix well to create the gravy consistency.
Increase the flame to medium-high and bring the curry to a boil.
Once it starts boiling, reduce the heat to medium and let the curry simmer.
Stir occasionally to prevent sticking and to ensure even cooking.
Allow the potatoes to absorb the flavors and cook until they turn soft.
If the gravy appears too thick, add more water to adjust the consistency as needed.
Taste and adjust the salt or chili powder according to preference.
Simmer for another 5 minutes, allowing all the flavors to blend well into the gravy.
Once the potatoes are fully cooked and the gravy reaches the desired thickness, turn off the heat.
Let the curry rest for a couple of minutes before serving.
Serve hot with steamed rice, chapati, or roti for a delicious meal.

Peel 1 kg of potatoes, chop them into medium-sized cubes, and keep them in water to prevent browning. Meanwhile, finely chop 1 kg of onions and 1 kg of tomatoes or blend the tomatoes into a smooth puree.
Heat 200 ml of oil in a large pan over medium heat and add the chopped onions. Saute them, stirring occasionally, until they turn soft and golden brown.
Sprinkle 2 tablespoons of chili powder over the onions and mix well to evenly coat them with the spice.
Add the chopped or pureed tomatoes to the pan, stir well, and cook until the tomatoes become mushy and the oil starts separating from the masala.
Drain the chopped potatoes and add them to the pan, mixing thoroughly to coat them with the onion-tomato masala.
Add 2 tablespoons of salt and stir everything together to evenly distribute the flavors.
Cover the pan with a lid and let the potatoes cook on low heat, stirring occasionally to prevent burning.
Pour 750 ml of water into the pan, stir well, and bring the curry to a boil over medium-high heat.
Once it starts boiling, reduce the heat to low and let the curry simmer, stirring occasionally to avoid sticking.
Check if the potatoes are fully cooked by piercing them with a fork; if they are still hard, let them cook for a few more minutes.
If the curry is too thick, add more water to adjust the consistency and mix well.
Let the curry simmer for another few minutes to allow all the flavors to blend.
Turn off the flame and let the curry rest for a couple of minutes before serving.
Garnish with freshly chopped coriander leaves if desired and serve hot with steamed rice, roti, or chapati.

Peel 1 kg of potatoes and chop them into small cubes, keeping them in water to prevent browning.
Finely chop 1 kg of onions and 1 kg of tomatoes, keeping them ready for cooking.
Heat 200 ml of oil in a large pan or kadhai over medium heat.
Add the chopped onions to the hot oil and Saute them until they turn soft and golden brown.
Stir occasionally to ensure even cooking and prevent burning.
Once the onions are golden, add 2 tablespoons of chili powder and mix well.
Stir for a few seconds to allow the chili powder to blend with the onions.
Add the chopped tomatoes and stir well to combine.
Cook the tomatoes until they become soft and the oil starts to separate from the mixture.
Keep stirring occasionally to avoid sticking to the pan.
Add the drained potato cubes to the pan and mix well with the onion-tomato mixture.
Stir continuously for a couple of minutes so the potatoes absorb the flavors.
Sprinkle 2 tablespoons of salt over the mixture and stir to combine.
Cook uncovered on medium heat for about 5 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Reduce the heat to low and cover the pan with a lid.
Let the potatoes cook in their own moisture, stirring occasionally to prevent burning.
Cook for another 10 minutes until the potatoes turn soft but still hold their shape.
Remove the lid and check if the potatoes are cooked through by pressing a piece with a spoon.
If needed, continue cooking uncovered for a few more minutes to remove excess moisture.
Stir frequently to ensure even cooking and crispiness.
Increase the heat slightly to allow the potatoes to develop a light crispy texture.
Stir-fry for another 5 minutes until the potatoes are golden brown.
Taste and adjust salt or chili powder if required.
Mix well to ensure the spices are evenly distributed.
Let the stir-fry cook for another 2 minutes for the flavors to blend well.
Turn off the heat and let the dish rest for a minute.
Garnish with freshly chopped coriander leaves if desired.
Transfer the spicy potato-tomato fry to a serving plate.
Serve hot as a side dish with rice, roti, or chapati.
Enjoy the crispy, spicy, and flavorful potato-tomato fry.

Wash 1 kg of chicken pieces thoroughly and set them aside.
Finely chop 1 kg of onions and 1 kg of tomatoes.
Peel and crush a handful of ginger and garlic into a smooth paste.
Heat 200 ml of oil in a large pan or kadhai over medium heat.
Add the chopped onions and Saute them until they turn golden brown, stirring occasionally.
Add the ginger-garlic paste and Saute until the raw smell disappears.
Stir continuously to ensure the paste doesn't stick to the bottom.
Add 2 tablespoons of chili powder, 1 tablespoon of turmeric, 1 tablespoon of garam masala, and 1 tablespoon of coriander powder.
Mix well and cook the spices for a minute to release their aroma.
Add the chopped tomatoes and mix well with the spices and onions.
Cook until the tomatoes become soft and the oil starts to separate from the masala.
Stir occasionally to prevent sticking.
Add the cleaned chicken pieces to the pan and mix well to coat them with the masala.
Cook on medium heat for 5 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Reduce the heat and cover the pan with a lid to allow the chicken to release its juices.
Let it cook for another 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Add 750 ml of water to adjust the consistency of the curry.
Stir well and bring the curry to a boil.
Lower the heat and let the curry simmer for 20 minutes.
Stir occasionally to ensure even cooking.
Check if the chicken is tender by piercing it with a fork.
If needed, cook for a few more minutes until the chicken is fully cooked.
Taste and adjust salt or spice levels if required.
Simmer for another 5 minutes to blend all flavors.
Turn off the heat and let the curry rest for a couple of minutes.
Garnish with freshly chopped coriander leaves.
Serve hot with steamed rice, roti, or naan.

Wash 1 kg of chicken thoroughly and set it aside.
Finely chop 1 kg of onions and 1 kg of tomatoes.
Crush a handful of ginger and garlic into a smooth paste.
Heat 200 ml of oil in a large pan over medium heat.
Add the chopped onions and Saute them until they turn golden brown, stirring occasionally.

Take 1 kg of eggplants and wash them thoroughly.
Roast the whole eggplants over an open flame or in an oven until the skin is charred and the flesh becomes soft.
Once roasted, let them cool for a few minutes.
Peel off the charred skin and mash the soft eggplant flesh using a fork or spoon.
Finely chop 1 kg of onions and 1 kg of tomatoes.
Crush a handful of garlic cloves into a smooth paste.
Heat 200 ml of oil in a large pan over medium heat.
Add the chopped onions and Saute them until they turn golden brown, stirring occasionally.
Add the crushed garlic paste and mix well until the raw smell disappears.
Stir in 2 tablespoons of chili powder, 1 tablespoon of turmeric, 1 tablespoon of garam masala, and 1 tablespoon of coriander powder.
Mix the spices well and cook for a minute until the oil separates from the mixture.
Add the chopped tomatoes and mix well with the onions and spices.
Cook until the tomatoes turn soft and blend completely into the masala.
Stir occasionally to prevent sticking to the pan.
Add the mashed eggplant to the pan and mix thoroughly with the masala.
Stir well to evenly distribute the flavors.
Cook uncovered on medium heat for about 5 minutes.
Stir occasionally to ensure even cooking.
Reduce the heat to low and let the mixture simmer for another 5 minutes.
Stir occasionally to prevent burning at the bottom.
Taste and adjust salt or spice levels if required.
Let the bharta cook for another few minutes to enhance the flavors.
Stir continuously to give the dish a smooth and uniform texture.
Turn off the heat and let the baingan bharta rest for a couple of minutes.
Garnish with freshly chopped coriander leaves for added aroma.
Serve hot with roti, naan, or steamed rice for a smoky and flavorful meal.

Wash 1 kg of lentils thoroughly and soak them in water for 30 minutes.
Finely chop 1 kg of onions and 1 kg of tomatoes.
Drain the soaked lentils and transfer them to a pressure cooker.
Add 2 liters of water, 1 tablespoon of turmeric, and salt to taste.
Close the lid and pressure cook for 5 whistles on medium heat.
Let the pressure release naturally before opening the cooker.
Mash the cooked lentils slightly for a smooth texture and set aside.
Heat 200 ml of butter in a large pan over medium heat.
Add the chopped onions and Saute until golden brown, stirring occasionally.
Add 1 tablespoon of cumin seeds and let them crackle.
Stir in 1 tablespoon of crushed garlic and Saute until the raw smell disappears.
Add 2 tablespoons of chili powder, 1 tablespoon of garam masala, and 1 tablespoon of coriander powder.
Stir well and cook the spices for a minute until the butter releases from the masala.
Add the chopped tomatoes and mix well with the onion-spice blend.
Cook until the tomatoes soften and blend into the mixture.
Stir occasionally to prevent burning at the bottom.
Pour the cooked lentils into the pan and mix well with the masala.
Adjust the consistency by adding 500 ml of water if required.
Let the dal simmer for 10 minutes on low heat, stirring occasionally.
Taste and adjust salt and spice levels as needed.
Heat 50 ml of butter in a small pan for tempering.
Add 1 teaspoon of cumin seeds, 2 dried red chilies, and a pinch of asafoetida.
Saute for 30 seconds until aromatic, then pour the tempering over the dal.
Mix well and let the dal rest for 2 minutes to absorb the flavors.
Garnish with freshly chopped coriander leaves for extra aroma.
Serve hot with steamed rice, roti, or naan for a delicious meal.

Heat 250 ml of oil in a pan over medium heat.
Wash and cut 1 kg of eggplant into medium-sized pieces.
Add the eggplant to the hot oil and fry until golden brown, then remove and set aside.
In the same pan, add 1 teaspoon of mustard seeds and let them splutter.
Finely chop 1 kg of tomatoes and add them to the pan.
Cook the tomatoes until they turn soft and mushy.
Add 2 tablespoons of red chili powder, 2 tablespoons of turmeric powder, and 2 tablespoons of coriander powder.
Stir well and cook for 3 minutes until the spices release their aroma.
Soak 200 grams of tamarind in 500 ml of warm water for 10 minutes.
Squeeze the tamarind and extract the juice, discarding the pulp.
Pour the tamarind juice into the pan with the tomatoes and spices.
Stir well and bring the mixture to a boil.
Add 1 teaspoon of salt and mix well.
Carefully add the fried eggplant into the tamarind gravy.
Stir gently to coat the eggplant with the curry.
Cover the pan and let it simmer for 10 minutes on low heat.
Taste and adjust the salt and spice levels as needed.
If a thicker consistency is preferred, let it cook uncovered for a few minutes.
Add a pinch of jaggery or sugar to balance the tanginess of the tamarind.
Stir well and let the curry simmer for another 5 minutes.
Heat 50 ml of oil in a separate small pan for tempering.
Add 1 teaspoon of mustard seeds and 1 teaspoon of cumin seeds.
Once they crackle, add 2 dried red chilies and 10 curry leaves.
Pour the tempering over the tamarind eggplant curry and mix well.
Garnish with freshly chopped coriander leaves.
Stir one last time before turning off the heat.
Let the dish rest for 5 minutes to enhance the flavors.
If serving later, reheat on low heat and add a little water if needed.
Transfer the tamarind eggplant curry into a serving bowl.
The eggplant should be soft and well-infused with the tangy tamarind flavors.
Drizzle a few drops of oil on top for added richness.
Serve hot with steamed rice or roti.
Let the dish rest for 2 minutes before serving.
If a spicier taste is preferred, add a few crushed red chili flakes before serving.
Enjoy the flavorful tamarind eggplant curry with your favorite meal.

Heat 250 ml of oil in a pan over medium heat.
Wash and cut 1 kg of eggplant into thin slices or small cubes.
Add the eggplant to the hot oil and fry until golden brown and soft, then remove and set aside.

Finely chop 1 kg of tomatoes and add them to the pan.
Saute the tomatoes until they turn soft and release their juices.
Add 2 tablespoons of red chili powder, 2 tablespoons of turmeric powder, and 2 tablespoons of coriander powder.
Stir well and cook for 3 minutes until the spices are well blended with the tomatoes.
Soak 200 grams of tamarind in 500 ml of warm water for 10 minutes.
Squeeze the tamarind and extract the juice, discarding the pulp.
Pour the tamarind juice into the pan and mix well with the tomato mixture.
Add 2 tablespoons of jaggery or sugar to balance the spiciness and enhance the sweetness.
Stir and let the mixture simmer for 5 minutes until it thickens slightly.
Carefully add the fried eggplant into the sweet and spicy sauce.
Stir gently to coat the eggplant pieces evenly with the sauce.
Cover and let it cook on low heat for 5 minutes to absorb the flavors.
Taste and adjust the salt, sweetness, or spice as needed.
If a thicker consistency is preferred, cook uncovered for a few more minutes.
Heat 50 ml of oil in a small pan for tempering.
Add 1 teaspoon of mustard seeds and let them crackle.
Add 1 teaspoon of cumin seeds and 2 dried red chilies.
Toss in 10 curry leaves and Saute for a few seconds.
Pour the tempering over the sweet and spicy eggplant fry and mix well.
Sprinkle 1 teaspoon of garam masala for extra flavor.
Stir everything together and let it rest for 5 minutes.
Garnish with freshly chopped coriander leaves for added freshness.
Stir one last time before turning off the heat.
Transfer the eggplant fry to a serving bowl.
Drizzle a few drops of oil on top for a glossy finish.
If serving later, reheat on low heat and add a little water if needed.
Serve hot with steamed rice, roti, or as a side dish.

If a spicier taste is preferred, add crushed red chili flakes before serving.

Store any leftovers in an airtight container and refrigerate for later use.

Rinse 1 kg of lentils thoroughly under running water and soak them in water for 30 minutes.
Heat 250 ml of oil in a large pot over medium heat.
Finely chop 1 kg of onions and add them to the pot.
Saute the onions until they turn soft and golden brown.
Finely chop 1 kg of tomatoes and add them to the onions.
Stir well and cook until the tomatoes turn soft and blend into the mixture.
Add 2 tablespoons of turmeric powder, 2 tablespoons of red chili powder, and 2 tablespoons of coriander powder.
Mix well and let the spices cook for 2 minutes.
Drain the soaked lentils and add them to the pot.
Stir everything together so the lentils get coated with the onion-tomato mixture.
Pour 2 liters of water into the pot and bring it to a boil.
Reduce the heat and let the lentils simmer for 20 minutes until they start softening.
Stir occasionally to prevent sticking.
Wash and chop 1 kg of spinach leaves finely.
Add the chopped spinach to the lentil mixture.
Stir well and let it cook for another 10 minutes.
Taste and adjust the salt, spice, or consistency by adding more water if needed.
If a thicker consistency is preferred, let it simmer uncovered for a few more minutes.
Heat 50 ml of oil in a small pan for tempering.
Add 1 teaspoon of mustard seeds and let them crackle.
Add 1 teaspoon of cumin seeds and 2 dried red chilies.
Toss in 10 curry leaves and Saute for a few seconds.
Pour the tempering over the spinach lentil soup and mix well.
Stir everything together and let it simmer for 5 minutes.
Sprinkle 1 teaspoon of garam masala for extra flavor.
Stir well and turn off the heat.
Let the soup rest for 5 minutes to absorb all the flavors.
If serving later, reheat on low heat and add water if needed.
Transfer the soup into a serving bowl.
Garnish with freshly chopped coriander leaves.
Drizzle a few drops of ghee or butter on top for extra richness.
Serve hot with steamed rice or bread.
Stir one last time before serving.
If a spicier taste is preferred, add crushed red chili flakes before serving.
Enjoy the hearty and nutritious spinach lentil soup.

Wash 1 kg of lentils thoroughly under running water until the water runs clear.
Soak the lentils in warm water for 20 minutes to help them cook faster.
In a large pot, heat 3 tablespoons of oil over medium heat.
Add 1 kg of finely chopped onions and Saute them until they turn golden brown.
Crush and add 5 garlic cloves to the onions, stirring well.
Add 1 teaspoon of cumin seeds and let them crackle for 10 seconds.
Finely chop 1 kg of tomatoes and mix them into the onions.
Add 1 teaspoon of salt and stir well to soften the tomatoes quickly.
Cook for 5 minutes until the tomatoes become mushy and blend with the onions.
Add 1 teaspoon of turmeric powder, 2 teaspoons of red chili powder, and 1 teaspoon of coriander powder.
Mix the spices well and cook for another 2 minutes to enhance the flavors.
Drain the soaked lentils and add them to the pot.
Pour in 2 liters of water and stir everything together.
Cover the pot and let it simmer over medium heat for 30 minutes until the lentils become soft.
Wash and finely chop 1 kg of spinach, removing any thick stems.
Add the chopped spinach to the cooked lentils and mix well.
Let the spinach cook for 5 minutes until it wilts completely.
Adjust the salt and spice levels as per taste.
Mash a portion of the lentils with the back of a spoon for a creamy texture.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a small pan for tempering.
Add 1 teaspoon of mustard seeds and let them splutter.
Toss in 1 teaspoon of cumin seeds and stir for 10 seconds.
Finely chop 5 garlic cloves and fry them until golden brown.
Add 1 teaspoon of red chili powder to the tempering and mix quickly.
Pour the hot tempering over the dal and immediately cover with a lid to trap the aroma.
Stir everything well and let the dal sit for 5 minutes to absorb the flavors.
Serve the hot Palak Dal Tadka with steamed rice or roti.
Garnish with freshly chopped coriander leaves before serving.
Drizzle a little oil or butter on top for added richness.
If making ahead, store in an airtight container and refrigerate for up to 2 days.
Reheat before serving, adding a little water if the dal thickens too much.
Enjoy this nutritious and flavorful lentil dish with your favorite side!

Wash 1 kg of cauliflower thoroughly and cut it into medium-sized florets.
Boil water in a large pot, add the cauliflower, and let it blanch for 5 minutes.
Drain the water and set the cauliflower aside.
Heat 3 tablespoons of oil in a large pan over medium heat.
Add 1 kg of finely chopped onions and Saute until they turn golden brown.
Crush and add 5 garlic cloves, stirring well for 1 minute.
Add 1 teaspoon of cumin seeds and Saute for 10 seconds until aromatic.
Finely chop 1 kg of tomatoes and add them to the pan.
Stir well and cook for 5 minutes until the tomatoes turn soft and mushy.
Add 1 teaspoon of salt to help break down the tomatoes faster.
Mix in 1 teaspoon of turmeric powder, 2 teaspoons of red chili powder, and 1 teaspoon of coriander powder.
Stir well and cook the spices for 2 minutes until the oil starts separating.
Add the blanched cauliflower florets to the masala mixture.
Stir to coat the cauliflower evenly with the spices.
Cover the pan and let it cook for 5 minutes over low heat.
Pour in 1 cup of water and mix well to create a thick gravy.
Cover and simmer for 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Check if the cauliflower is tender by piercing it with a fork.

Stir in 2 tablespoons of crushed garlic and Saute for 2 minutes.
