Transfer the urad dal batter to a large mixing bowl.  

Drain the soaked rice and grind it separately, adding water little by little.  

Grind the rice until it becomes a smooth yet slightly grainy paste.  

Pour the ground rice batter into the urad dal batter and mix them well.  

Ensure the batter is well combined and has a thick, flowing consistency.  

Cover the bowl and let the batter ferment in a warm place overnight.  

Fermentation may take about 8 to 12 hours, depending on the temperature.  

After fermentation, the batter should rise and appear airy with bubbles.  

Add salt and gently stir the batter without overmixing.  

Heat a non-stick or cast-iron tawa over medium heat and grease it with oil.  

Once the pan is hot, pour a ladleful of batter in the center.  

Using the back of the ladle, spread the batter in circular motions to form a thin dosa.  

Drizzle a few drops of oil around the edges to make it crispy.  

Cook the dosa for a couple of minutes until the bottom turns golden brown.  

If you prefer, flip the dosa and cook for a few more seconds.  

For a traditional crisp dosa, you can avoid flipping and fold it instead.  

Remove the dosa and transfer it to a serving plate.  

Repeat the process with the remaining batter, greasing the pan as needed.  

If the pan gets too hot, sprinkle some water to cool it before making the next dosa.  

Serve the hot dosa with coconut chutney, sambar, or tomato chutney.  

For a masala dosa, place spiced potato filling inside and fold.  

Dosas can also be served with butter or ghee for extra flavor.  

Enjoy your crispy, golden, and delicious homemade dosa!

Rinse the rice thoroughly in water 213 times until the water runs clear.  

Soak the rice in enough water for at least 6 hours.  

In another bowl, rinse the urad dal well and soak it separately.  

Allow the urad dal to soak for at least 4 to 6 hours.  

Drain the soaked urad dal and transfer it to a grinder.  

Add a little water gradually and grind until you get a smooth, fluffy batter.  

Transfer the urad dal batter to a large mixing bowl.  

Drain the soaked rice and grind it separately, adding water little by little.  

Grind the rice until it forms a smooth yet slightly grainy batter.  

Pour the ground rice batter into the urad dal batter and mix well.  

Stir the batter thoroughly to ensure even consistency.  

Cover the bowl and allow the batter to ferment overnight in a warm place.  

Fermentation takes about 8 to 12 hours, depending on the temperature.  

Once fermented, the batter will rise and develop a slightly airy texture.  

Add salt to the batter and gently mix it without over-stirring.  

Grease the idli molds with a few drops of oil to prevent sticking.  

Pour the batter into each mold, filling about 1 of the space.  

Preheat a steamer with enough water for steaming.  

Place the idli stand inside the steamer and cover it with a lid.  

Steam the idlis for about 10 to 15 minutes on medium heat.  

Insert a toothpick or knife into an idli to check if it comes out clean.  

Once done, turn off the heat and let the idlis rest for a couple of minutes.  

Use a spoon or wet knife to gently remove the idlis from the molds.  

Transfer the soft and fluffy idlis to a serving plate.  

Serve hot with coconut chutney, sambar, or spicy tomato chutney.  

For extra flavor, drizzle ghee or butter over the idlis before serving.  

Leftover idlis can be refrigerated and later steamed again for freshness.  

Enjoy your light, soft, and delicious homemade idlis!

Roast the semolina in a dry pan over medium heat until it turns slightly golden and aromatic.  

Stir continuously to avoid burning and ensure even roasting.  

Transfer the roasted semolina to a mixing bowl and let it cool.  

In a separate bowl, whisk the yogurt until it turns smooth and lump-free.  

Slowly add the yogurt to the semolina while mixing to form a thick batter.  

Add a little water if needed to adjust the consistency.  

Let the batter rest for about 15 to 20 minutes to allow the semolina to absorb moisture.  

Heat oil in a small pan and add mustard seeds.  

Once the mustard seeds start spluttering, add finely chopped green chilies.  

Saute for a few seconds until the chilies release their aroma.  

Pour this tempering mixture into the idli batter and mix well.  

Add salt to taste and stir to combine all the ingredients evenly.  

If the batter becomes too thick, add a little more water or yogurt to loosen it.  

Grease the idli molds lightly with oil to prevent sticking.  

Add fruit salt or baking soda to the batter and mix gently.  

Immediately pour the batter into the idli molds, filling each about 1 full.  

Preheat a steamer and add enough water for steaming.  

Place the idli stand inside the steamer and cover it with a lid.  

Steam the rava idlis for about 10 to 12 minutes on medium heat.  

Check for doneness by inserting a toothpick; it should come out clean.  

Turn off the heat and let the idlis rest for a couple of minutes before removing them.  

Use a spoon or wet knife to gently lift the idlis from the molds.  

Transfer the soft and fluffy rava idlis to a serving plate.  

Serve hot with coconut chutney, tomato chutney, or sambar.  

Drizzle some ghee over the idlis for extra flavor if desired.  

Enjoy your quick, delicious, and spongy homemade rava idlis!

Dry roast the rice in a pan on low heat for a few minutes until aromatic.  

In a separate pan, dry roast the lentils until they turn slightly golden.  

Rinse the roasted rice and lentils thoroughly under running water.  

Transfer them to a pressure cooker and add enough water for cooking.  

Cook on medium heat for about 3 to 4 whistles until soft and mushy.  

Allow the pressure to release naturally before opening the lid.  

Mash the cooked mixture slightly to get a creamy consistency.  

Soak the tamarind in warm water for about 10 minutes.  

Extract the tamarind pulp by squeezing and straining it.  

Heat oil or ghee in a pan and add mustard seeds.  

Once they start spluttering, add dried red chilies and curry leaves.  

Add finely chopped green chilies and Saute for a few seconds.  

Sprinkle in turmeric powder and mix well.  

Pour the tamarind extract into the pan and stir continuously.  

Add salt, black pepper, and any preferred spices for enhanced flavor.  

Allow the tamarind mixture to simmer for a few minutes until it thickens.  

Pour the seasoned tamarind mixture into the cooked rice and lentils.  

Mix everything thoroughly, ensuring an even blend of flavors.  

Cook on low heat for a few more minutes while stirring.  

Add more water if needed to adjust the consistency to your liking.  

Drizzle some ghee over the Pongal for extra richness and taste.  

Garnish with freshly chopped coriander leaves.  

Serve hot with coconut chutney, sambar, or pickle.  

Enjoy your delicious, aromatic, and comforting tamarind Pongal!

Rinse the poha under running water for a few seconds until it softens.  

Drain excess water completely and let it rest for about 5 minutes to absorb moisture.  

Gently fluff the poha with a fork to separate the flakes without breaking them.  

Heat oil in a pan over medium heat and add mustard seeds.  

Wait for the mustard seeds to splutter, then add finely chopped green chilies.  

Saute for a few seconds until the chilies release their aroma.  

Add finely chopped onions and stir-fry until they turn soft and translucent.  

Sprinkle a pinch of salt over the onions to help them cook faster.  

Add turmeric powder and mix well to coat the onions evenly.  

Stir in a handful of roasted peanuts for extra crunch and flavor.  

Lower the heat and gently add the softened poha to the pan.  

Mix everything thoroughly, ensuring the poha absorbs the turmeric color evenly.  

Sprinkle salt as per taste and mix again to distribute the seasoning.  

Cover the pan and let it cook on low heat for a couple of minutes.  

Stir occasionally to prevent sticking and ensure even cooking.  

If the poha feels too dry, sprinkle a few drops of water to retain moisture.  

Add a teaspoon of sugar for a slight balance of flavors if desired.  

Turn off the heat and squeeze fresh lemon juice over the poha.  

Mix well to enhance the tangy flavor and freshness.  

Garnish with finely chopped coriander leaves for a vibrant touch.  

Optionally, top with grated coconut for extra texture and taste.  

You can also sprinkle some sev or fried peanuts for crunchiness.  

Let the flavors blend for a minute before serving.  

Serve hot with a cup of tea or as a wholesome breakfast dish.  

Enjoy the delicious and aromatic Kanda Poha with your favorite chutney!

Sieve the gram flour to remove lumps and transfer it to a mixing bowl.  

Add turmeric powder, salt, and a pinch of sugar for balance.  

Gradually add yogurt and mix well to form a smooth batter.  

Slowly add water while stirring to achieve a thick yet pourable consistency.  

Whisk the batter for a few minutes to incorporate air for fluffiness.  

Let the batter rest for about 15-20 minutes for better fermentation.  

Meanwhile, grease a steaming tray or plate with oil.  

Just before steaming, add fruit salt (eno) or baking soda to the batter.  

Mix gently in one direction; you1ll see the batter become frothy.  

Immediately pour the batter into the greased tray.  

Place the tray in a preheated steamer and cover with a lid.  

Steam for about 15-20 minutes on medium heat until cooked through.  

Check doneness by inserting a toothpick; it should come out clean.  

Once done, remove the tray and let it cool slightly.  

Invert the tray and cut the dhokla into square or diamond pieces.  

For tempering, heat oil in a small pan and add mustard seeds.  

Once the seeds splutter, add sesame seeds and green chilies.  

Pour in a little water along with sugar and a squeeze of lemon juice.  

Mix well and pour the tempering evenly over the dhokla.  

Garnish with freshly chopped coriander and grated coconut.  

Let the dhokla absorb the tempering for a few minutes.  

Serve warm with green chutney or sweet tamarind chutney.  

Enjoy soft, spongy, and flavorful Khaman Dhokla with a side of tea!

Take two slices of bread and spread butter evenly on one side of each slice.  

Flip the bread slices and place grated or sliced cheese on the unbuttered side of one slice.  

Optionally, sprinkle a pinch of salt, pepper, or chili flakes for extra flavor.  

Place the second slice of bread on top with the buttered side facing outward.  

Heat a pan or griddle over medium heat and place the sandwich on it.  

Cook for 2-3 minutes until the bottom turns golden brown and crispy.  

Press the sandwich gently with a spatula to ensure even cooking.  

Flip the sandwich carefully and cook the other side until golden brown.  

If the cheese hasn1t melted completely, lower the heat and cook for another minute.  

For extra crispiness, cover the pan with a lid for a short time.  

Remove the sandwich from the pan and let it cool slightly before slicing.  

Cut diagonally or into halves and serve hot.  

Optionally, add tomato slices, basil, or cooked bacon for variation.  

Serve with ketchup, mayonnaise, or a side of soup.  

Enjoy a crispy, cheesy, and delicious grilled cheese sandwich!

Take two slices of fresh bread and spread butter evenly on one side of each slice.  

Wash and thinly slice cucumber and tomatoes.  

Optionally, sprinkle a little salt and pepper on the slices for added taste.  

Place the cucumber slices evenly over one buttered bread slice.  

Layer the tomato slices over the cucumbers.  

If desired, add a pinch of chaat masala or a dash of lemon juice for extra flavor.  

Cover with the second slice of bread, buttered side facing inward.  

Gently press the sandwich to hold the ingredients in place.  

If you prefer, trim the edges of the bread for a neater look.  

For a soft sandwich, serve it as is, or for a crispy version, toast or grill it.  

Cut the sandwich diagonally or into halves for easy serving.  

Serve with ketchup, green chutney, or mayonnaise for extra taste.  

Pair it with a cup of tea or fresh juice for a refreshing meal.  

Enjoy a quick, fresh, and delicious vegetable sandwich!

Take a saucepan and add milk, bringing it to a gentle boil over medium heat.  

Gradually add oats while stirring continuously to avoid lumps.  

Lower the heat and let the oats simmer, stirring occasionally.  

Cook for about 5-7 minutes until the oats become soft and creamy.  

If you prefer a thicker consistency, cook for a few more minutes.  

Turn off the heat and let the oatmeal rest for a minute.  

Drizzle honey over the oatmeal for natural sweetness.  

Mix well to evenly distribute the honey.  

Chop nuts such as almonds, walnuts, or cashews into small pieces.  

Sprinkle the chopped nuts over the oatmeal for crunch and nutrition.  

Optionally, add dried fruits like raisins or cranberries for extra flavor.  

For a richer taste, stir in a pinch of cinnamon or vanilla extract.  

You can also add a sliced banana or fresh berries for natural sweetness.  

Give the oatmeal a final stir and transfer it to a serving bowl.  

If you prefer a thinner consistency, add a little more warm milk.  

Serve warm and enjoy a healthy, nourishing bowl of oatmeal!

Take a mixing bowl and add chickpea flour (besan).  

Finely chop onions and tomatoes, then add them to the chickpea flour.  

Add a pinch of salt, turmeric powder, red chili powder, and cumin powder for flavor.  

You can also add chopped green chilies and ginger for extra spice.  

Gradually add water to the flour mixture, stirring continuously to make a smooth batter.  

Ensure the batter is of a pouring consistency, not too thick or too runny.  

Let the batter sit for 5-10 minutes, allowing the flavors to meld together.  

Heat a non-stick pan or tawa over medium heat and lightly grease it with oil.  

Once the pan is hot, pour a ladleful of the batter and spread it into a circular shape.  

Let it cook for a few minutes until the edges of the chilla start to lift up.  

Drizzle a little oil around the edges for a crispy texture and let it cook on medium heat.  

After 2-3 minutes, flip the chilla carefully using a spatula.  

Cook the other side until it turns golden brown and crispy.  

Press the chilla gently with a spatula to ensure it cooks evenly.  

Once both sides are crisp and golden, remove the chilla from the pan.  

Repeat the process with the remaining batter, greasing the pan lightly in between.  

Serve the besan chilla hot, paired with green chutney, tomato ketchup, or curd.  

Garnish with freshly chopped coriander leaves for extra flavor.  

You can also add a squeeze of lemon juice for a tangy touch.  

For variation, you can add grated vegetables like carrots or spinach to the batter.  

Enjoy your savory and healthy besan chilla as a breakfast or snack option!

Take a mixing bowl and add wheat flour.  

Add a pinch of salt to the flour to enhance the flavor.  

In a separate bowl, add a small amount of baking soda and mix it with the flour.  

Gradually add yogurt to the mixture, stirring constantly to incorporate it smoothly.  

The yogurt helps make the appams soft and gives them a slight tangy flavor.  

Continue to mix while adding water little by little until the batter reaches a smooth consistency.  

The batter should be thicker than pancake batter but not too stiff.  

Whisk the batter well to ensure there are no lumps.  

Let the batter rest for about 30 minutes to allow the flour to absorb the yogurt and activate the baking soda.  

Meanwhile, heat an appam pan (or a small non-stick pan) over medium heat.  

Once the pan is hot, lightly grease it with a little oil or ghee using a paper towel or a small brush.  

Pour a ladleful of the batter into the center of the pan.  

Immediately tilt the pan in a circular motion so the batter spreads evenly around the edges.  

Cover the pan with a lid and let it cook for 2-3 minutes until the edges become golden and crispy.  

The center should remain soft and spongy, while the edges will turn crispy and slightly browned.  

Once the appam has cooked, remove it from the pan carefully using a spatula.  

Repeat the same process for the remaining batter, greasing the pan as needed.  

Serve the appams immediately, hot from the pan, with a side of coconut chutney, vegetable curry, or stew.  

If you prefer a sweeter version, you can serve them with sugar or jaggery syrup.  

Enjoy the soft, fluffy texture of these appams with their crispy edges and delicious flavor!

Take a mixing bowl and add wheat flour.  

Add a pinch of salt to the flour for flavor.  

Gradually add water to the flour and knead to form a smooth dough.  

Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 15-20 minutes.  

Meanwhile, peel and boil potatoes until soft.  

Mash the boiled potatoes in a separate bowl until smooth.  

Add chopped onions, green chilies, and coriander leaves to the mashed potatoes.  

Sprinkle in spices like cumin powder, garam masala, red chili powder, and salt to taste.  

Mix the filling thoroughly to combine the spices and potatoes well.  

Divide the dough into small equal-sized balls.  

Take one ball of dough and roll it into a small disc using a rolling pin.  

Place a spoonful of the potato filling in the center of the dough circle.  

Carefully fold the edges of the dough over the filling to form a ball again.  

Roll the stuffed dough ball gently into a flat, round paratha.  

Heat a tawa or flat pan over medium heat and grease it with a little oil or ghee.  

Place the rolled paratha on the hot tawa and cook for 2-3 minutes.  

Once the bottom side has brown spots, flip the paratha and cook the other side.  

Apply a little oil or ghee on both sides and cook until golden brown and crispy.  

Repeat the process for the remaining dough balls and filling.  

Serve the aloo parathas hot with yogurt, pickle, or a side of curry.  

Enjoy the crispy, soft parathas with a flavorful spiced potato filling!

Take a mixing bowl and add cornmeal (makki ka atta).  

Add a pinch of salt to the cornmeal for seasoning.  

Gradually add water to the cornmeal, stirring constantly to avoid lumps.  

Continue adding water until the mixture forms a smooth, thick batter.  

Let the batter sit for a few minutes while you prepare the cooking ingredients.  

Heat a pan over medium heat and add a little oil.  

Once the oil is hot, add mustard seeds and let them splutter.  

Add curry leaves, chopped green chilies, and ginger.  

Saute for a minute until the spices release their aroma.  

Now, pour the cornmeal mixture into the pan.  

Stir well to combine the spices and the cornmeal mixture.  

Cook the upma mixture, stirring occasionally, until it starts to thicken.  

Add more water if the upma becomes too thick during cooking.  

Cover the pan and let it cook for a few minutes to allow the cornmeal to soften.  

Once the mixture becomes soft and has absorbed all the water, it1s ready.  

Garnish the upma with freshly chopped coriander leaves for extra flavor.  

You can also add a squeeze of lemon juice for a tangy twist.  

Serve the hot upma with chutney or pickles.  

Enjoy this delicious and comforting upma as a light meal or snack!

Mash ripe bananas in a mixing bowl until smooth.  

Add jaggery to the mashed bananas and stir well until it dissolves completely.  

Add a pinch of cardamom powder to the mixture for a fragrant flavor.  

Gradually add flour (whole wheat or all-purpose) to the banana mixture.  

Stir the mixture to combine the flour with the banana and jaggery mixture.  

Add water or milk little by little to make a thick batter that can be poured easily.  

Ensure the batter has a smooth consistency, not too runny or too thick.  

Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and lightly grease it with oil or ghee.  

Once the pan is hot, pour a ladleful of the batter onto the pan.  

Spread the batter slightly into a round shape with the back of the ladle.  

Cook the pancake for about 2-3 minutes or until the edges start to brown.  

Flip the pancake carefully using a spatula and cook the other side until golden brown.  

Remove the pancake from the pan and place it on a plate.  

Repeat the process with the remaining batter, greasing the pan as needed.  

Serve the banana pancakes hot, drizzled with honey or topped with fresh fruits.  

You can also enjoy them with a dollop of yogurt or whipped cream.  

The sweet and aromatic pancakes are ready to be savored!

Start by soaking the rice in water for about 4-5 hours.  

Once soaked, drain the water and spread the rice on a clean cloth to dry for a few hours.  

After the rice is dried, grind it into a coarse powder using a blender or a traditional grinding stone.  

Take the ground rice flour and transfer it to a large mixing bowl.  

Add a pinch of salt to the rice flour to balance the flavor.  

Now, grate the fresh coconut and set it aside.  

Add jaggery to the rice flour mixture, adjusting the amount depending on how sweet you want the puttu.  

Mix the jaggery well with the rice flour, ensuring it is evenly distributed.  

Gradually add water to the mixture, little by little, to form a moist, crumbly texture.  

The mixture should be damp enough to hold together when pressed but not too wet.  

Take a puttu maker (a special steamer used for making puttu) and grease it lightly with ghee or oil.  

First, layer some grated coconut at the bottom of the puttu maker.  

Then, add a layer of the rice flour and jaggery mixture.  

Repeat the process by layering coconut and the rice mixture until the puttu maker is full.  

Once filled, securely close the puttu maker and place it in a steamer.  

Steam the puttu for about 10-12 minutes or until it becomes firm and fully cooked.  

Once done, remove the puttu from the steamer and carefully unmold it.  

Serve the hot puttu with extra coconut, a drizzle of ghee, or as an accompaniment to curry or stew.  

Enjoy the sweet, aromatic flavor of this traditional dish!

Start by preparing the rice flour dough. In a mixing bowl, add rice flour, a pinch of salt, and gradually add warm water to form a smooth dough.  

Once the dough is ready, cover it with a damp cloth and set it aside.  

Now, prepare the filling by taking grated coconut in a separate bowl.  

Add jaggery to the coconut and mix well until the jaggery is dissolved and the mixture becomes sticky.  

Add a pinch of cardamom powder to the coconut and jaggery mixture to enhance the flavor.  

You can also add a few chopped nuts for extra texture, if desired.  

Next, take a few large banana leaves and wipe them clean with a damp cloth.  

Cut them into small, square or rectangular pieces, large enough to hold the rice flour dough and filling.  

Lightly grease the banana leaves with a little ghee or oil to prevent the mixture from sticking.  

Take a small portion of the rice flour dough and flatten it into a thin, round disc.  

Place a spoonful of the coconut and jaggery filling in the center of the disc.  

Carefully fold the edges of the banana leaf over the rice dough to enclose the filling, making a neat packet.  

Repeat the process with the remaining dough and filling, ensuring all the packets are tightly sealed.  

Steam the prepared patholis in a steamer for about 20-25 minutes or until the rice dough is cooked and firm.  

You can also place a damp cloth over the patholis while steaming to retain moisture.  

Once done, remove the patholis from the steamer and allow them to cool slightly.  

Serve the delicious, aromatic patholis warm, drizzled with a little ghee.  

These sweet, coconut-filled rice parcels are perfect as a snack or dessert!

Start by washing the black gram (urad dal) and rice thoroughly under running water.  

Soak the rice and black gram in water for about 4-6 hours to soften them.  

After soaking, drain the water and transfer the rice and black gram into a blender.  

Add a little water to help blend the mixture and grind it into a smooth batter.  

The consistency of the batter should be similar to that of pancake batter 1 thick but spreadable.  

Once ground, transfer the batter to a bowl and cover it. Allow the batter to ferment for 6-8 hours or overnight.  

After fermentation, the batter should rise slightly and develop a tangy aroma.  

Now, take a non-stick griddle or a tawa and heat it over medium heat.  

Lightly grease the surface with oil or ghee to prevent the batter from sticking.  

Take a ladle of the fermented batter and pour it onto the hot griddle.  

Quickly spread the batter in a circular motion to form a thin, even pancake.  

Cook for about 2-3 minutes until the edges begin to lift and the bottom turns golden brown.  

Drizzle a little oil around the edges of the pesarattu for added crispiness.  

Flip the pesarattu carefully and cook the other side for another 2-3 minutes.  

Once both sides are crisp and golden, remove it from the griddle and place it on a plate.  

Serve the hot pesarattu with coconut chutney or ginger chutney on the side.  

Enjoy the crispy, savory flavor of this traditional Andhra breakfast dish!

Start by washing the fenugreek leaves (methi) thoroughly to remove any dirt or impurities.  

Chop the fenugreek leaves finely and set them aside.  

In a large mixing bowl, add wheat flour and a pinch of salt.  

Add the finely chopped fenugreek leaves to the flour.  

Next, add spices such as cumin seeds, turmeric powder, red chili powder, and carom seeds (ajwain) for flavor.  

You can also add a pinch of asafoetida (hing) for added taste, if desired.  

Add a teaspoon of oil to the flour mixture to make the dough softer and more pliable.  

Gradually add water to the flour and spice mixture, kneading it into a smooth, soft dough.  

Once the dough is ready, cover it with a damp cloth and let it rest for about 10-15 minutes.  

Divide the dough into small, equal-sized balls.  

Roll each ball into a smooth ball and flatten it slightly with your palms.  

Using a rolling pin, roll out each dough ball into a thin, round disc.  

Sprinkle some dry flour while rolling to prevent the dough from sticking.  

Heat a tawa or griddle over medium heat and lightly grease it with oil or ghee.  

Place the rolled-out dough onto the hot tawa and cook for about 1-2 minutes until small bubbles form on the surface.  

Flip the thepla and apply a little oil or ghee on the cooked side.  

Flip again and cook until both sides are golden brown and crisp.  

Repeat the process for the remaining dough balls, greasing the tawa as needed.  

Serve the hot methi theplas with yogurt, pickle, or any chutney of your choice.  

Enjoy the soft and flavorful theplas, perfect for breakfast or a snack!

Start by mixing chickpea flour (besan) and yogurt in a large mixing bowl.  

Add a pinch of salt and spices like turmeric, cumin powder, coriander powder, and red chili powder to the mixture.  

If you prefer a little heat, you can also add some garam masala or crushed black pepper.  

Mix the ingredients thoroughly to combine them into a smooth batter.  

Gradually add a little water, as needed, to achieve a consistency that is neither too thick nor too runny1similar to cake batter.  

Let the batter rest for about 15 minutes so that the flavors meld together.  

While the batter is resting, heat a little oil in a pan and add mustard seeds.  

Once the mustard seeds begin to splutter, add a pinch of hing (asafoetida) and some sesame seeds for extra crunch and flavor.  

Pour this tempering (tadka) into the batter and stir it in to distribute evenly.  

Optionally, you can add chopped green chilies, grated ginger, or finely chopped cilantro for added flavor.  

Next, grease a baking dish or a cake pan with a little oil.  

Pour the batter into the greased dish, smoothing the top with a spatula.  

Preheat the oven to about 1801C (3501F).  

Bake the handvo in the preheated oven for around 25-30 minutes, or until the top turns golden brown and a toothpick inserted comes out clean.  

While the handvo is baking, heat a small amount of oil in a pan and prepare a tadka with mustard seeds, curry leaves, and dried red chilies.  

Once the handvo is baked, remove it from the oven and pour the hot tadka over the top.  

Let the handvo cool for a few minutes before cutting it into slices or squares.  

Serve the handvo warm with green chutney or yogurt on the side.  

Enjoy this savory, spicy, and slightly tangy Gujarati delicacy!

Start by washing the millets (ragi) thoroughly to remove any impurities.  

Dry roast the ragi in a pan over medium heat for about 2-3 minutes, until it gives off a mild, nutty aroma.  

Once roasted, add the ragi to a saucepan along with water.  

The water-to-millet ratio should be about 1:2.5. Bring it to a boil over medium heat, stirring occasionally to prevent lumps.  

Once the water starts boiling, reduce the heat and allow it to simmer.  

Stir the mixture continuously to avoid any sticking or burning at the bottom. Cook until the mixture thickens and the ragi absorbs the water.  

Once the ragi has cooked and the mixture turns into a thick, dough-like consistency, remove it from the heat.  

Let it cool slightly, allowing it to firm up.  

Meanwhile, in a separate pan, heat a little ghee or oil and add grated coconut.  

Saute the coconut for about 2 minutes until it becomes slightly golden brown and aromatic.  

Add jaggery to the coconut and mix until the jaggery melts into the coconut, forming a sticky mixture.  

Add a pinch of cardamom powder to the mixture for added flavor and aroma.  

Now, gently mix this coconut-jaggery mixture into the cooked ragi dough.  

Mix well until the dough is uniformly combined with the sweet coconut and jaggery filling.  

Once everything is combined, shape the mixture into small, round balls (mudde) using your hands.  

If the dough feels too sticky, you can grease your hands with a little ghee to make shaping easier.  

Serve the ragi mudde warm with extra ghee or a side of curry, chutney, or yogurt.  

Enjoy the nutritious, sweet, and aromatic ragi mudde as a wholesome meal or snack!

Start by combining maida (all-purpose flour) and sugar in a mixing bowl.  

Gradually add milk to the flour and sugar mixture, stirring continuously to avoid lumps.  

Mix well to form a smooth, thick batter. The consistency should be similar to pancake batter, not too runny or too thick.  

Let the batter rest for about 10-15 minutes, allowing the ingredients to combine well.  

While the batter is resting, heat a little ghee in a pan or deep frying pan over medium heat.  

Once the ghee is hot, add a pinch of cardamom powder to the batter for extra fragrance and flavor.  

Optionally, you can add a few drops of rose water or kewra water to enhance the aroma.  

Check the temperature of the ghee by dropping a small amount of batter into it; if it sizzles and rises to the surface immediately, the ghee is ready.  

Now, pour a ladle of the batter into the hot ghee, spreading it gently to form a small round pancake.  

Fry the malpua until both sides turn golden brown and crisp, turning them carefully to ensure even frying.  

Once done, remove the malpua from the ghee and place it on a paper towel to drain excess oil.  

Repeat the process with the remaining batter, adding more ghee as needed to fry each malpua.  

After frying all the malpua, heat a small amount of ghee in a separate pan.  

Add sugar to it and melt it into a syrup by simmering for a few minutes.  

Once the sugar syrup reaches a slightly thick consistency, pour it over the hot malpua.  

Allow the malpua to soak in the syrup for a few minutes, allowing them to absorb the sweetness.  

Serve the malpua warm, garnished with chopped nuts or dry fruits if desired.  

Enjoy this rich and sweet treat, perfect for festivals or special occasions!

Start by washing the flattened rice (aval) thoroughly to remove any dust or impurities.  

Drain the water and set the flattened rice aside to soak for about 5-10 minutes, just until it softens slightly.  

In a separate pan, heat a little ghee and add grated coconut to it.  

Saute the coconut for 2-3 minutes until it turns light golden and releases a pleasant aroma.  

Add jaggery to the pan and stir until it melts completely, forming a syrupy consistency.  

While the jaggery melts, cut a banana into small slices or pieces.  

Once the jaggery has melted and the coconut syrup is smooth, add the soaked flattened rice to the pan.  

Gently mix the flattened rice with the jaggery-coconut mixture, ensuring that each grain of rice is coated evenly with the syrup.  

Next, add the chopped banana pieces to the mixture and mix them gently to combine.  

Cook the mixture for a couple of minutes on low heat, allowing the banana to soften slightly.  

Make sure the mixture is well blended, with the jaggery syrup, coconut, and banana evenly distributed throughout the flattened rice.  

Once everything is combined, remove the pan from the heat.  

You can add a pinch of cardamom powder for an extra burst of fragrance if you prefer.  

Serve the Aval Nanachathu warm or at room temperature.  

This dish can also be enjoyed as a quick breakfast, snack, or dessert.  

The sweetness of jaggery and the richness of coconut make this dish a delicious and healthy treat!

Start by preparing the banana leaves by washing them thoroughly. Cut them into square or rectangular pieces, depending on the size you want for each ada.  

Heat the banana leaves over an open flame for a few seconds to soften them, making them more pliable and easier to fold. Set them aside to cool.  

In a mixing bowl, combine rice flour and a pinch of salt.  

Gradually add water to the rice flour while mixing continuously, until you get a smooth dough. The dough should be soft and pliable, not too sticky or too dry.  

In another bowl, mix grated coconut and jaggery together. Stir until the jaggery melts into the coconut, creating a sticky filling.  

Once the jaggery and coconut are well combined, you can add a pinch of cardamom powder for fragrance if you prefer.  

Now, take one banana leaf and place a small portion of the rice flour dough in the center of the leaf.  

Flatten the dough into a small, round shape with your fingers or a spoon.  

Place a spoonful of the jaggery-coconut filling in the center of the dough.  

Fold the banana leaf over the dough to form a small parcel, making sure the edges are sealed well to prevent the filling from spilling out.  

Repeat this process with the remaining dough and filling, creating several parcels.  

Next, steam the prepared ada parcels in a steamer or a large pot with a steaming rack.  

Steam for about 15-20 minutes on medium heat, or until the rice flour is cooked and the ada is firm to touch.  

After steaming, remove the parcels from the steamer and let them cool slightly before unwrapping.  

Serve the Ela Ada warm or at room temperature.  

This sweet treat is a traditional Kerala snack, enjoyed for its unique flavor of coconut, jaggery, and rice flour. It1s perfect for festivals or as a delicious dessert!

Start by heating a little oil in a pan or pressure cooker.  

Add chopped onions and Saute until they become soft and translucent.  

Once the onions are cooked, add any desired spices like cumin seeds, mustard seeds, or a pinch of turmeric for flavor.  

You can also add green chilies or ginger if you want some heat and flavor.  

Stir the spices and onions together until the mixture becomes aromatic.  

Next, add the pearl millet flour (bajra flour) to the pan, and Saute it for 2-3 minutes to lightly roast the flour.  

This helps in removing any raw taste from the millet flour and enhances its flavor.  

Now, add yogurt to the mixture, stirring continuously to avoid any lumps from forming.  

Once the yogurt is well incorporated, add water to the pan to form a smooth, porridge-like consistency.  

Season the mixture with salt to taste and bring it to a simmer.  

Cover the pan and let the khichdi cook on low heat for about 10-12 minutes, stirring occasionally.  

If you are using a pressure cooker, cook it for 2-3 whistles.  

Once the khichdi thickens and the millet flour is fully cooked, remove it from the heat.  

You can adjust the consistency by adding more water or yogurt if needed.  

Garnish the Bajra Khichdi with fresh coriander leaves, a dollop of yogurt, or some ghee for added richness.  

Serve it hot, either as a wholesome meal or as a nutritious breakfast.  

This hearty and nutritious khichdi is a great gluten-free option, rich in fiber and perfect for digestion!

Start by washing and draining the corn kernels. If you're using fresh corn, grate or blend it into a fine paste. If using canned or frozen corn, drain and blend it into a smooth paste.  

In a mixing bowl, combine the corn paste with rice flour and a pinch of salt.  

Add buttermilk to the mixture, gradually, to form a smooth batter with a consistency similar to pancake batter. Stir the batter well to remove any lumps.  

You can add spices like cumin powder, red chili powder, or turmeric for extra flavor. Feel free to add finely chopped green chilies or ginger for a bit of heat.  

Heat a non-stick or cast iron tawa (griddle) on medium heat and lightly grease it with oil or ghee.  

Once the tawa is hot, pour a ladle of the corn-rice flour batter onto it, spreading it into a circular shape with the back of the ladle.  

Cook the cheela on medium heat until the edges start to lift and it becomes golden brown at the bottom.  

Flip the cheela carefully and cook the other side until it1s also golden brown and slightly crisp.  

Repeat the process for the remaining batter, greasing the tawa as needed.  

Serve the Makki Ka Cheela hot, garnished with coriander leaves or a dollop of yogurt on the side.  

This dish is perfect as a savory breakfast, snack, or light meal, offering a delicious combination of flavors and textures!

Start by boiling the potatoes until soft. Once cooked, peel and mash them in a bowl.  

In another bowl, add buckwheat flour (kuttu ka atta) and season with salt, cumin powder, and red chili powder.  

Add the mashed potatoes to the flour and mix well to combine.  

Gradually add water to form a soft dough. Be careful not to add too much water at once, as buckwheat flour absorbs moisture quickly.  

Knead the dough until it becomes smooth and pliable. If the dough is too sticky, dust it with a little more buckwheat flour.  

Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for about 10-15 minutes.  

After resting, divide the dough into small portions and roll each portion into a ball.  

Take one ball and flatten it with your palms. Dust it lightly with buckwheat flour to prevent it from sticking.  

Roll the dough ball into a flat, round shape, using a rolling pin. Be gentle as buckwheat flour can be delicate.  

Heat a tawa or griddle on medium heat and add a little ghee or oil.  

Place the rolled-out paratha onto the hot tawa and cook for 1-2 minutes, until small bubbles begin to form on the surface.  

Flip the paratha and cook the other side, pressing it gently with a spatula to ensure even cooking.  

Drizzle a little more ghee or oil on both sides and cook until both sides are golden and crispy.  

Repeat with the remaining dough portions.  

Serve the Kuttu Paratha hot with yogurt, chutney, or pickle on the side for a delicious gluten-free meal.  

This paratha is perfect for fasting or as a nutritious, gluten-free alternative to regular parathas.

Start by soaking the sprouted moong beans in water for a few hours if they1re not already sprouted. Drain the water and set the beans aside.  

In a mixing bowl, add the sprouted moong, finely chopped green chilies, and freshly chopped coriander leaves.  

Season the mixture with salt, cumin powder, black pepper, and a pinch of turmeric for added flavor.  

Add a little water or buttermilk to make a smooth batter, ensuring the consistency is similar to pancake batter.  

You can also add finely chopped onions, tomatoes, or any other vegetables you prefer for added crunch and flavor.  

Heat a non-stick tawa or pan on medium heat and lightly grease it with oil.  

Once the tawa is hot, pour a ladle of the moonglet batter onto it and spread it into a thick, round shape with the back of the ladle.  

Cook the moonglet on medium heat until the bottom turns golden brown, about 2-3 minutes.  

Flip the moonglet carefully and cook the other side until it becomes golden brown as well.  

Repeat the process with the remaining batter, greasing the tawa as needed.  

Serve the Moonglet hot with a side of chutney, yogurt, or pickle.  

This nutritious and savory snack is packed with protein and fiber, making it a great choice for breakfast or as a light meal.

Start by taking semolina (rava) in a large mixing bowl and add yogurt to it. Mix well to combine, ensuring there are no lumps.  

Gradually add water to the mixture, stirring continuously until the batter reaches a thick yet pourable consistency, similar to pancake batter.  

Add salt, a pinch of turmeric, and your choice of spices such as cumin seeds or red chili powder for flavor.  

Grate carrots and add them to the batter, mixing them in evenly. You can also add chopped green chilies or ginger for extra spice if desired.  

Let the batter rest for about 10-15 minutes to allow the semolina to absorb the moisture and soften.  

In the meantime, heat a non-stick tawa or a griddle on medium heat and lightly grease it with oil.  

Once the tawa is hot, pour a ladle of the batter onto it, spreading it into a thick, round shape using the back of the ladle.  

Cook the uttapam on medium heat, allowing it to cook slowly so the inside gets properly cooked.  

After 2-3 minutes, flip the uttapam carefully and cook the other side until golden brown and slightly crisp.  

Repeat with the remaining batter, greasing the tawa as needed.  

Serve the Rava Uttapam hot with coconut chutney or sambar on the side for a delicious and filling meal.  

This dish is perfect for breakfast or as a savory snack, offering a good balance of carbs, protein, and fiber.

Soak rice in water for about 3-4 hours. Once soaked, drain the water and transfer the rice to a blender.  

Add fresh coconut (grated or desiccated) to the blender along with some water, and blend until it forms a smooth paste.  

Next, add sugar and a pinch of salt to the rice-coconut mixture and blend again.  

Pour the blended mixture into a mixing bowl and add enough water to achieve a thin, pourable batter consistency.  

Heat a non-stick tawa or griddle on medium heat and lightly grease it with ghee.  

Once the tawa is hot, pour a ladle of the batter onto it, spreading it evenly to form a thin, round dosa.  

The batter will spread out easily because of its thin consistency, so you do not need to use a spatula.  

Cook the Neer Dosa on medium heat for about 1-2 minutes until the edges begin to lift and the surface appears set.  

Do not flip the dosa as it is delicate and soft. Let it cook on one side only.  

Once cooked, gently lift the dosa off the tawa with a spatula and fold it.  

Serve the Neer Dosa hot with coconut chutney, sambar, or any curry of your choice for a light, delicious meal.  

This dish is typically enjoyed for breakfast or as a snack and is a popular coastal cuisine specialty known for its light and soft texture.

Start by mashing the ripe bananas in a bowl until smooth, ensuring there are no large chunks.  

Add wheat flour to the mashed banana and mix well.  

Add jaggery to the mixture, making sure it dissolves completely in the batter. If the jaggery is in solid form, melt it slightly before adding.  

Add a pinch of cardamom powder to the batter for flavor, and mix everything together.  

To adjust the consistency, add a little water or milk if the batter feels too thick. It should be thick but still pourable.  

Let the batter rest for about 15 minutes to allow the flour to absorb the moisture and thicken slightly.  

Meanwhile, heat a paniyaram pan (or an appe pan) on medium heat and lightly grease each cavity with ghee or oil.  

Once the pan is hot, spoon the banana batter into each cavity, filling them about three-fourths full.  

Cook the paniyarams on medium-low heat for about 2-3 minutes, allowing the edges to cook and become golden brown.  

Once the edges are cooked, gently flip the paniyarams using a spoon or skewer to cook the other side.  

Cook for another 2-3 minutes, making sure both sides are evenly browned and crispy.  

Once cooked, remove the banana paniyarams from the pan and place them on a serving plate.  

Serve them hot with coconut chutney or enjoy them as a sweet snack.  

These banana paniyarams are soft on the inside, slightly crispy on the outside, and packed with natural sweetness from the banana and jaggery. They make for a delicious and healthy snack or breakfast option.

Start by washing the Fox Millet (Thinai) thoroughly under cold water to remove any dirt.  

In a heavy pan, dry roast the Fox Millet on low heat for 3-4 minutes until it releases a light fragrance. This helps enhance its flavor.  

Once roasted, transfer the millet to a pressure cooker. Add water in a 1:2 ratio (1 cup millet to 2 cups water).  

Cook the millet for 2-3 whistles or until the millet is soft and fully cooked. Turn off the heat and let the pressure release naturally.  

While the millet is cooking, take a separate pan and heat a little ghee over medium heat.  

Add grated fresh coconut and Saute for a minute until it turns slightly golden and aromatic.  

Next, add jaggery to the pan and stir until it melts completely into the coconut. If needed, you can add a tablespoon of water to help the jaggery melt faster.  

Once the jaggery is melted, check for sweetness and adjust by adding more jaggery if desired.  

After the millet is cooked, fluff it up using a fork to separate the grains.  

Combine the cooked millet with the jaggery-coconut mixture, mixing well to ensure that the sweet coconut mixture coats the millet evenly.  

Add a pinch of cardamom powder for flavor and mix well.  

Let the Thinai Pongal cook on low heat for an additional 2-3 minutes, allowing the flavors to blend together.  

Once everything is well-mixed, turn off the heat.  

Serve the Thinai Pongal warm as a sweet breakfast dish or a dessert.  

This dish is nutritious, with the richness of millet, the sweetness of jaggery, and the creaminess of coconut, making it a healthy and satisfying meal.

Cook rice and let it cool to room temperature, or use leftover rice.  

In a separate bowl, whisk the curd (yogurt) to make it smooth and creamy. Add it to the cooled rice, mixing well to combine.  

Add salt to taste and stir to incorporate evenly throughout the rice and curd mixture.  

Heat oil in a small pan on medium heat. Once hot, add mustard seeds and let them splutter.  

Add curry leaves to the hot oil and fry them for a few seconds until they turn crisp and aromatic.  

You can also add a pinch of hing (asafoetida) if desired, for extra flavor.  

Pour the tempering mixture (mustard seeds, curry leaves, and oil) over the curd rice and mix well.  

Optionally, you can garnish the curd rice with chopped coriander or grated carrot for additional flavor and color.  

Serve the Curd Rice chilled or at room temperature as a refreshing side dish with lunch or dinner.  

This simple and soothing dish is often served as a comfort food and is great for digestion. It can be enjoyed with pickles, papad, or any curry.

Peel and chop the sweet potatoes into small cubes. Boil or steam them until soft and tender, around 10-15 minutes.  

Once cooked, mash the sweet potatoes thoroughly until smooth and set them aside.  

In a separate pan, heat a little ghee over medium heat.  

Add the mashed sweet potatoes to the pan and Saute for a few minutes to allow them to cook further and absorb the ghee.  

Next, add grated coconut to the pan and mix it with the sweet potatoes. Stir well to combine.  

Add jaggery to the mixture and stir continuously until it melts completely and blends with the sweet potatoes and coconut.  

Adjust the sweetness by adding more jaggery if necessary.  

Cook the mixture on low heat, stirring occasionally, until it thickens and the ghee starts to separate from the mixture.  

Add cardamom powder to the halwa for extra flavor and stir it in well.  

If the mixture becomes too thick, you can add a little milk to reach the desired consistency.  

Once the halwa is cooked and has reached a thick, smooth consistency, turn off the heat.  

Garnish with chopped nuts like cashews or almonds for a crunchy texture.  

Serve the Sweet Potato Halwa warm as a dessert or a sweet snack.  

This rich and delicious halwa is naturally sweetened with jaggery and packed with the goodness of sweet potatoes and coconut.

Rinse the sago (sabudana) thoroughly under cold water to remove excess starch. Soak it in water for about 4-6 hours or overnight, ensuring the sago is just about soaked but not too mushy.  

Drain the soaked sago and set it aside, letting any excess water drain off completely.  

In a pan, heat some oil or ghee on medium heat. Add a handful of peanuts and roast them until they are crunchy and golden brown. Remove and set aside.  

In the same pan, add chopped potatoes and cook them until they are soft and lightly golden. Stir occasionally to prevent burning.  

Add chopped green chilies to the pan and Saute for a few seconds to release their flavor.  

Next, add the soaked sago to the pan and mix it well with the potatoes and chilies.  

Season with salt, and add a pinch of sugar for a slight sweetness, if desired. Stir everything together, ensuring the sago is evenly coated with the flavors.  

Cover the pan and cook the khichdi on low heat for about 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally to prevent sticking.  

Add the roasted peanuts to the mixture and stir them in gently.  

Cook for an additional 2-3 minutes, allowing the peanuts to infuse their flavor into the sago.  

Once the sago becomes translucent and the khichdi is cooked through, turn off the heat.  

Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and a squeeze of lemon juice for extra freshness and flavor.  

Serve the Sabudana Khichdi warm as a breakfast dish or light meal.  

This simple yet delicious dish is often enjoyed during fasting or as a comfort food, offering a perfect balance of crunchy peanuts, soft potatoes, and savory spices.

Rinse the moong dal thoroughly under cold water and soak it for 3-4 hours, or overnight if possible.  

Drain the soaked moong dal and grind it into a smooth batter using a little water. The batter should have a thick consistency, similar to pancake batter.  

Transfer the batter to a mixing bowl and add finely chopped green chilies, ginger, and any other spices like cumin powder, turmeric, or red chili powder to taste.  

Season the batter with salt and stir well to combine all the ingredients. You can also add a pinch of hing (asafoetida) for extra flavor.  

Heat a non-stick pan or griddle on medium heat and lightly grease it with oil or ghee.  

Once the pan is hot, pour a ladleful of the moong dal batter onto the pan, spreading it into a round shape, like a pancake.  

Cook the chilla for 2-3 minutes until the bottom side is golden brown and crispy. Then, flip it over and cook the other side for another 2-3 minutes.  

Repeat the process with the remaining batter, adding more oil or ghee to the pan as needed.  

Serve the Moong Dal Chillas hot with chutney, yogurt, or a side of salad.  

These savory chillas make a great snack, breakfast, or light meal and are rich in protein due to the moong dal, along with a delicious, spicy flavor.

Rinse the barnyard millet (sama rice) thoroughly under cold water to remove any impurities.  

Soak the millet in water for about 15-20 minutes, then drain and set aside.  

In a pressure cooker or a large pot, heat some oil or ghee over medium heat.  

Add cumin seeds and let them splutter. You can also add a few crushed black peppercorns for extra flavor.  

Add finely chopped ginger and green chilies to the pan and Saute for a few seconds until fragrant.  

Next, add finely chopped onions (optional) and Saute until they turn translucent.  

Add chopped vegetables like carrots, peas, and potatoes, if desired. Saute for another 2-3 minutes to soften the veggies.  

Now, add the soaked barnyard millet to the pan and stir it gently with the vegetables and spices.  

Season with salt, turmeric, and any other spices like garam masala or cumin powder according to your taste.  

Add water (about 2 cups for 1 cup of millet) and bring it to a boil.  

Once the water starts boiling, reduce the heat to low, cover the cooker or pot, and cook for 5-7 minutes (if using a pressure cooker, cook for 1-2 whistles).  

After the cooking time is done, let the pressure release naturally if using a cooker.  

Add curd (yogurt) to the khichdi and mix well, letting the curd blend with the millet and spices. This will give the khichdi a creamy texture.  

If you want, garnish with fresh coriander leaves and a drizzle of ghee for extra flavor.  

Serve the Sama Rice Khichdi hot with a side of pickle or raita for a complete meal.  

This dish is not only light and easy to digest but also rich in nutrients, making it perfect for fasting or a healthy, comforting meal.

Rinse the black rice thoroughly under cold water to remove any impurities.  

Soak the black rice in water for about 30 minutes to soften it.  

In a pot, add the soaked rice and enough water to cook it. Bring it to a boil, then lower the heat to simmer. Cook the rice for about 30-40 minutes or until it becomes tender.  

Once the rice is cooked, add coconut milk to the pot, stirring well to combine. Continue cooking on a low flame for 5-7 minutes, allowing the rice to absorb the coconut milk and get a creamy texture.  

Add jaggery to the pot and stir until it melts completely. The jaggery will give the kheer a rich sweetness.  

Add cardamom powder for a fragrant flavor, and stir to combine. If you like, you can add a pinch of saffron strands soaked in warm water for a golden color and aromatic fragrance.  

Allow the kheer to simmer for another 5-7 minutes, letting the flavors meld together.  

Once the kheer reaches your desired consistency (it should be thick and creamy), remove the pot from the heat.  

Garnish with chopped nuts such as cashews or almonds for a crunchy texture. You can also add grated coconut for extra richness.  

Serve the Chak Hao Kheer hot or chilled, depending on your preference.  

This unique dessert, made with black rice, is not only delicious but also packed with antioxidants and nutrients, making it a wholesome treat for any occasion.

Peel and wash the tapioca (kappa) thoroughly to remove any dirt and impurities.  

Cut the tapioca into small, bite-sized pieces for easy cooking.  

In a large pot, add enough water to submerge the tapioca pieces and bring it to a boil.  

Once the water starts boiling, add the tapioca pieces and cook for about 15-20 minutes, or until they become soft and tender.  

Drain the water and set the cooked tapioca aside.  

In a separate pan, heat some oil and add mustard seeds. Let them splutter, then add a pinch of cumin seeds and curry leaves for flavor.  

Add finely chopped ginger and green chilies to the pan and Saute for a minute until fragrant.  

Add the cooked tapioca to the pan and stir well, mixing it with the tempering.  

Now, add grated coconut to the tapioca and continue stirring. The coconut will add a rich texture and flavor.  

Add jaggery to the pan and stir until it melts completely, blending with the tapioca and coconut.  

Season with salt to taste and mix thoroughly. You can also add a pinch of turmeric for color and extra flavor.  

Cook for another 5-7 minutes, allowing the jaggery and coconut to fully blend with the tapioca.  

Serve the Kappa Puzhukku hot as a delicious side dish or a main course, typically enjoyed with fish curry or any other curry of your choice.  

This traditional dish is a perfect combination of the soft, starchy tapioca with the sweetness of jaggery and the richness of coconut.

Soak the sprouts (like moong beans or mixed sprouts) overnight or for 8 hours in water.  

Drain the water and rinse the sprouts well under cold water. Let them sprout for 1-2 days in a warm place.  

Once the sprouts are ready, transfer them to a large mixing bowl.  

Finely chop onions, tomatoes, and green chilies. Add them to the bowl with the sprouts.  

Squeeze fresh lemon juice over the sprouts mixture to add tanginess.  

Add a pinch of black salt and regular salt to taste.  

Sprinkle roasted cumin powder and red chili powder for flavor. Adjust the spice level as per your preference.  

Mix the ingredients well, making sure the spices and lemon juice coat the sprouts evenly.  

Add fresh coriander leaves for a refreshing, herby flavor.  

If desired, you can also add a bit of chopped cucumber or pomegranate seeds for extra crunch and sweetness.  

Toss the mixture gently to combine all the flavors.  

Serve the sprouts chaat immediately as a refreshing, healthy snack or appetizer.  

This chaat is light yet filling, packed with protein from the sprouts and bursting with vibrant flavors from the spices and lemon.

In a mixing bowl, combine chickpea flour (besan) with spices like red chili powder, turmeric, cumin powder, garam masala, and salt to taste.  

Add a pinch of asafoetida (hing) for extra flavor.  

Gradually add water to the mixture, a little at a time, and mix to form a smooth, thick batter. The batter should be able to hold its shape but not too stiff.  

Heat oil in a deep frying pan or kadhai over medium heat for frying the pakoras.  

Once the oil is hot, test it by dropping a small amount of batter into the oil. If it sizzles and rises to the surface, the oil is ready for frying.  

Now, drop spoonfuls of the batter into the hot oil, making small fritters or pakoras. Don't overcrowd the pan, as this will reduce the oil temperature.  

Fry the pakoras until golden brown and crispy, turning occasionally to ensure they cook evenly. This should take about 4-5 minutes.  

Once crispy, remove the pakoras from the oil and drain them on a paper towel to absorb any excess oil.  

Serve the pakoras hot with green chutney or tamarind chutney for dipping.  

These crispy, spicy chickpea flour fritters are perfect for tea-time or as a snack for any occasion.

Boil the potatoes in water until they are soft and tender, which should take around 10-15 minutes depending on the size of the potatoes. Drain the water and let the potatoes cool down for a few minutes.  

Once cooled, peel the potatoes and mash them using a potato masher or fork until smooth.  

In a small bowl, mix together spices such as red chili powder, cumin powder, garam masala, coriander powder, and a pinch of salt. You can also add finely chopped green chilies and coriander leaves for extra flavor.  

Add the spice mixture into the mashed potatoes and mix well. To bind the mixture, add some cornflour, which will help the tikkis hold their shape and become crispy when fried.  

If you'd like a bit of texture, you can add finely chopped onions, peas, or even some grated ginger to the potato mixture.  

Take small portions of the mixture and roll them into smooth balls. Flatten them gently to form round or oval patties (tikkis).  

Heat oil in a non-stick frying pan or shallow frying pan over medium heat. You need enough oil to fry the tikkis, but not so much that they1re submerged completely.  

Once the oil is hot, place the tikkis in the pan. Don1t overcrowd the pan; fry in batches if necessary to ensure even cooking.  

Fry the tikkis for about 3-4 minutes on each side, or until they turn golden brown and crispy. Use a spatula to flip them gently to avoid breaking.  

Once the tikkis are crispy and golden, remove them from the oil and place them on a paper towel to absorb excess oil.  

Serve the aloo tikkis hot with a side of green chutney, tamarind chutney, or yogurt. They are perfect for a snack, a starter, or even as a part of a meal.  

These crispy, spiced potato patties are a favorite street food and will be loved by everyone!

Start by rinsing the poha (flattened rice) thoroughly in water to soften it. Once done, drain any excess water and set the poha aside for a few minutes to ensure it's not too wet.  

In a pan, heat a tablespoon of oil over medium heat. Add finely chopped onions and Saute them until they become soft and translucent.  

Next, add spices like turmeric, red chili powder, garam masala, and cumin powder to the onions. Stir well to combine and let the spices cook for a minute or two until they release their aroma.  

Add a pinch of salt to the mixture to enhance the flavor. Optionally, you can also add some finely chopped green chilies for an extra kick.  

Once the onions and spices are well-cooked, add the softened poha to the pan. Stir everything together gently, making sure the poha is coated well with the spices and onions. Cook for about 2-3 minutes, ensuring everything is evenly mixed.  

Turn off the heat and allow the poha mixture to cool down slightly. Once it's cool enough to handle, transfer it to a mixing bowl.  

To bind the mixture, add some mashed boiled potatoes and mix well. The potatoes will help in holding the cutlet together.  

You can add finely chopped coriander leaves, peas, or even grated carrots at this stage for extra flavor and texture.  

Now, shape the mixture into small patties or round cutlets using your hands.  

Next, heat some oil in a pan or shallow fry the cutlets. Once the oil is hot, place the cutlets in the pan. Fry them for about 2-3 minutes on each side, or until they turn golden brown and crispy.  

Once fried, remove the poha cutlets from the pan and drain any excess oil on a paper towel.  

Serve the poha cutlets hot with a side of green chutney, tamarind chutney, or yogurt for dipping.  

These crispy and flavorful poha cutlets make for a perfect snack or appetizer, and they1re sure to be a hit with family and friends.

Wash and boil 1 kg of potatoes until soft. Peel and mash them in a large bowl.
Heat 100 ml of oil in a pan over medium heat.
Add 2 tbsp of cumin seeds and let them crackle.
Mix in grated ginger (4 tbsp) and chopped green chilies (8-10), Sauteing for a minute.
Add turmeric powder (2 tbsp), red chili powder (4 tbsp), coriander powder (2 tbsp), garam masala (2 tbsp), and salt as per taste.
Stir well to blend the spices evenly with the oil.
Add the mashed potatoes to the pan and mix thoroughly. Cook for 2-3 minutes.
Turn off the heat, add 1 cup of chopped coriander leaves, and mix well.
Let the mixture cool completely before shaping the rolls Trim the edges of the bread slices if desired (optional).

Gently press the wet bread slice between palms to remove excess water while keeping it soft. Place 1-2 tbsp of the prepared potato filling in the center of each moistened bread slice.

Press firmly and shape into smooth oval or cylindrical forms.
Repeat this process for all slices, maintaining uniform size. Heat 2 liters of oil in a deep pan or kadhai over medium-high heat.
Test the oil by dropping a small piece of bread1if it rises and sizzles immediately, the oil is ready.

Fry them evenly, turning occasionally, until golden brown and crispy.

Heat a heavy-bottomed pan over low heat.

Heat on medium flame, stirring continuously to dissolve the sugar completely.
Let it cook until it reaches one-string consistency (when a drop of syrup pressed between fingers forms a single thread).
Reduce the heat to low once the syrup reaches the right consistency. Slowly add the roasted gram flour to the sugar syrup in batches while continuously stirring.
Stir well to ensure no lumps are formed, creating a smooth mixture. Begin adding the warm melted ghee (1 kg) in portions while stirring continuously.
The mixture will absorb the ghee and start thickening.
Continue stirring as the mixture turns glossy and porous.
If a softer texture is desired, add 250 ml of oil along with the ghee. Keep stirring on medium-low heat, allowing the ghee to be fully absorbed.
The mixture will start leaving the sides of the pan and become slightly grainy and porous.
To check readiness, take a small portion and drop it on a plate1if it solidifies quickly, the mixture is ready.
Turn off the heat immediately to prevent overcooking. Grease a large tray or plate with ghee.
Quickly pour the hot mixture onto the tray and spread it evenly using a spatula.
Tap the tray gently to remove air bubbles and ensure a uniform surface.
Let it cool for about 10-15 minutes until it starts to set but is still warm. Using a sharp knife, cut the Mysore Pak into squares or diamond shapes while it is still warm.
Allow it to cool completely at room temperature before removing the pieces.
Once fully set, store in an airtight container to maintain freshness. Serve Mysore Pak at room temperature as a sweet delicacy.
It pairs well with hot beverages like tea or coffee.
Store in an airtight container for up to 2-3 weeks.

Drizzle 1 cup of lemon juice for a tangy flavor.

Rinse 1 kg of sabudana (sago) under running water until the water runs clear.

Fry until they turn golden brown and crispy on all sides.
Remove and drain excess oil using paper towels. Serve hot with mint chutney, tamarind chutney, or yogurt dip.

Take 1 kg of corn kernels and rinse them thoroughly.

ake 1 kg of flour (maida) and sift it in a large mixing bowl.
